stem: The nurse is caring for a 6-month-old infant, Bobby, diagnosed with Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). Based on the information provided in the EHR, which of the following interventions are MOST important for the nurse to implement? Select all that apply.

itemContext.sbar: S: Bobby Smith, a 6-month-old male infant, diagnosed with Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), was admitted at 07:00 for increased cyanosis and respiratory distress. His current oxygen saturation is 78% on room air. Respiratory rate is 48 breaths per minute, and heart rate is 180 beats per minute. O: Upon assessment, the infant exhibits circumoral cyanosis and nasal flaring. B: The mother reports that Bobby has been more irritable and feeding poorly over the past 24 hours. She indicates a history of “tet spells.” Bobby was diagnosed with TOF at 2 weeks of age and has been followed by cardiology. A: Currently, Bobby is experiencing a hypercyanotic spell, likely due to increased pulmonary vascular resistance and decreased systemic vascular resistance. Immediate interventions are crucial to improve oxygenation and stabilize his condition. R: I am requesting orders for morphine sulfate IV, oxygen administration via nasal cannula, and guidance on knee-chest positioning. I have prepared Propranolol IV for possible administration if the spell continues. Please notify me immediately if there is no improvement within 5 minutes. Labs were drawn at 07:15. The current time is 07:20.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
07:00: HR 180, RR 48, SpO2 78% (RA), Temp 37.2°C (Axillary), BP 90/60 mmHg
06:00: HR 160, RR 40, SpO2 85% (RA), Temp 37.0°C (Axillary), BP 92/62 mmHg

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: 07:15: Hgb 18 g/dL, Hct 54%, WBC 12,000/mm3, Na 138 mEq/L, K 4.2 mEq/L, Cl 100 mEq/L, HCO3 24 mEq/L, pH 7.30, pCO2 50 mmHg, pO2 55 mmHg

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Morphine Sulfate IV PRN for hypercyanotic spells (0.1 mg/kg) - Last given: N/A
Propranolol IV PRN for hypercyanotic spells (0.01 mg/kg) - Last given: N/A
Oxygen per nasal cannula - titrate to maintain SpO2 >85%

rationale.correct: Placing the infant in a knee-chest position increases systemic vascular resistance, which helps to decrease the right-to-left shunt and subsequently improve pulmonary blood flow, leading to increased oxygen saturation. Administering morphine sulfate helps to decrease pulmonary vascular resistance and reduce agitation, further improving oxygenation. Administering oxygen helps to increase the oxygen saturation. Frequent monitoring of vital signs is crucial to assess the effectiveness of interventions and detect any deterioration in the infant's condition. Preparing to administer Propranolol IV will help to decrease HR and decrease the severity of the hypercyanotic spell.
rationale.incorrect: Encouraging the mother to breastfeed during a hypercyanotic spell is contraindicated because it increases the infant's oxygen demand and can exacerbate the spell. Drawing arterial blood gases (ABGs) is important for monitoring the infant's overall status, but it is not the immediate priority during a hypercyanotic spell. Applying a cool compress to the forehead will not help to resolve a hypercyanotic spell, although it could be used to address fever. Elevating the head of the bed alone is not sufficient to improve oxygenation during a hypercyanotic spell; the knee-chest position is more effective in this situation.
clinicalPearls: Hypercyanotic spells (tet spells) are characterized by a sudden increase in cyanosis, respiratory distress, and agitation in infants with Tetralogy of Fallot.
The primary goal during a tet spell is to reduce pulmonary vascular resistance and increase systemic vascular resistance to improve oxygenation.
Knee-chest position is a simple yet effective intervention to increase systemic vascular resistance and improve blood flow.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting actions that are generally appropriate for respiratory distress but do not specifically address the underlying pathophysiology of a tet spell, such as routine oxygen administration without addressing the shunt.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the specific interventions aimed at decreasing pulmonary vascular resistance and increasing systemic vascular resistance in the context of Tetralogy of Fallot, considering the physiological mechanisms behind each intervention.

mnemonic.title: K-MOP
mnemonic.expansion: Knee-chest, Morphine, Oxygen, Propranolol. Remembering these interventions helps to manage hypercyanotic spells effectively.
